Posts.Content: Hi Ceecee, I noticed that I was losing quite a lot of hair. Seemed to be loads of it would fall in the sink when I was combing it. I have now been using Plantur 39. It is designed for hormone induced hair loss. ( decreasing levels of estrogen). It does seem to work. I buy mine from Boots. It costs about £10 a bottle, but could be worth giving a try. Maggie x
Posts.Title: Letrozole - hair thinning

Posts.Content: Hi Jojomomo, I am so sorry, you do sound as if you are having an awful time of it. Can't help at all with advice I am afraid, but just wanted to let you know I'm here.  Stick with it I am sure that in time you will recover. and begin to feel better. I am not surprised that you are peeed off with it all. Try to do what you really feel like doing over Christmas whatever it is you feel like. Roast dinner in the freezer for anyone who disagrees. THEY can heat it up in the microwave!!!! You just have what you fancy, Chocolate and wine comes to mind. I am sure you wont need to worry about the delay before Radiotherapy. it is designed to zap any cancer cells that may have been left behind. So if they are there they wont stand a chance. Take care and be kind to yourself. Maggie x
Posts.Title: Feels Neverending....

Posts.Content: HI Angela, Forget about your age love when it comes to a comfy bra, if it looks pretty, fits well and you like it that is all you need to concern yourself with. Pretty underwear is for all of us!! I think I heard that M&S do a range of mastectomy bras have you looked at them? It is harder sometimes if you live alone, there isn't anyone next to you for when you need a cuddle, a shoulder to cry on or someone to let off steam to. At least on this site you get as much support as you need from people who are going through the same as you. I have found close friends invaluable. Family can be very good but you often hide how you are really feeling because you don't want to upset them so its difficult sometimes. Keep your chin up, you are doing really well and will eventually get used to the 'new' you. Maggie x
Posts.Title: Anastraloze side effects and older ladies without family.

Posts.Content: Hi Angela, I really should have said that I too live alone and I do understand that it is quite hard sometimes. It's no joke when these appointments come round and that too I understand. Try to be as relaxed as you can I know that's easier said than done. Comfort yourself a little with the knowledge that if anything does go wrong in the early days you are being 'checked' up on regularly so anything odd will be caught very early on. Can you give yourself a little treat while you are getting close to appointments, something nice to help you feel a little pampered maybe?  You are being really positive and that is good but we all feel low and worried and have a little wobble sometimes. Thinking off you and sending you love and a (much needed?) hug. Maggie x
Posts.Title: Anastraloze side effects and older ladies without family.

Posts.Content: Hi Caz, Glad to hear that you are doing so well. Fantastic news. Don't know if this helps but I have just one nail with a problem, it splits from the tip to the base. I have been using No 7 Ridge filling base and then applying nail varnish over the top. It doesn't heal it, but does protect and hide the problem. Take care of yourself, remember to be kind to yourself as you go through your Radiotherapy and please don't push yourself to hard. If you feel tired, then rest. I found it helpful to have easy meals in the freezer which only needed zapping in the microwave when I was having mine. It was so easy when I felt washed out.  Wishing you all the best. Maggie x
Posts.Title: Good news for a change

Posts.Content: Hi London Lass, I am so sorry that all this nonsense has happened while you are grieving you friend. It is so hard when we lose people we care about. We all need support to keep us going and hugs even virtual and animal ones are vital and give us a lift. Don't worry about the awake thread even if it's permanently closed, we have another one here! I have seen somethings similar to this happen on other sites. It just seems to be the way it goes sometimes, everyone is different and some people just seem to react with anger. Instead cast your mind back to Saturday. We all had a lovely time. That's what it's all about support, laughter and happy times to counteract the times when we feel low  and overwhelmed by the whole thing. Onwards and upwards everyone. Let's put it all behind us and start again. Love and hugs to you all Maggie xx
Posts.Title: GREAT TIMING......

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn, The first time I was diagnosed with bc I always referred to the op as my boob job. It made it all less scary and I didn't want people to feel sorry for me. I think it's a much more comfortable way of looking at it. I mean you know you've got cancer but don't want to be reminded all the time do you.  Take care Maggie x
Posts.Title: One stop breast clinic

Posts.Content: Hi Jo, Wow I see you are begining to heal at last. That must be such a relief. I am so very pleased for you and hope that now healing has begun it will rapidly improve. Maggie x
Posts.Title: Efficacy of Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi there, totally agree. Eat less, move more. The best thing to do with coffee is drink it!! Love and hugs  Maggie xx
Posts.Title: Green coffee extract

Posts.Content: Great news. So pleased for you. Now you can enjoy the festivities I hope this year. Maggie x
Posts.Title: 1st year mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi Shaz, I think a quick call to your BCN might be in order. At the very least she can advise or maybe arrange another appointment. She might even be able to reassure you. Either way I would think that that would be better than worrying yourself senseless over it. I hope you will get a positive outcome to your phone call. Sending you a hug. Maggie x
Posts.Title: Abdominal pain on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi Jj1, I totally get where you are coming from. At my first year mammogram I was in bits. I couldn't stop crying while I was waiting my turn. I felt a total idiot because I had been doing fine up until then. I think that a year on you are probably still feeling fragile inside even though most of the time you are ok. Don't worry. It does get easier as time goes by. Be kind to yourself while you await your results and try to enjoy yourself. Then, when you have a positive outcome to the mammogram, celebrate and have fun.  Maggie x
Posts.Title: First year follow up mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi there, just wanted to say Good luck. I remember my first one 12 months after diagnosis, I was terrified, I cried! It was all ok, but until the letter came I was very worried. Try not to get too worked up about it if you can. I think the best advise is to try to do something you will enjoy this weekend to lift your spirits and give Cancer thoughts a good kick away from you. Don't let worry ruin your life. All the best. Maggie x
